etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in Geoffrey Chaucer (c1340–1400), poet and administrator. Apparently partly (i) from Middle French amourete, amourette (French amourette) superficial love affair, sweetheart, lover from amour love + -ette

definitions: A sweetheart, lover, or paramour; especially a female one. Compare "amoretto". Chiefly archaic and literary in later use.
A representation of Cupid; a cupid. Compare amorino, "amoretto".
